thread.title: Chinese Super League season kicks-off after £320m spending spree… in front of EMPTY 52,888-seater stadium
thread.title_full: Chinese Super League season kicks-off after £320m spending spree… in front of EMPTY 52,888-seater stadium

author: whaughton
title: Chinese Super League season kicks-off after £320m spending spree… in front of EMPTY 52,888-seater stadium
text:
Mo Money No Fans Chinese Super League season kicks-off after £320m spending spree… in front of EMPTY 52,888-seater stadium 
Embarrassingly Guizhou Zhicheng's game against Lianoning Whowin was played in front of no fans to kick off the new Chinese Super League season Pictured 3rd March 2017, 4:20 pm Updated: 3rd March 2017, 7:14 pm Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments THE CHINESE SUPER LEAGUE is awash with cash – but it’s not exactly brimming with fans as the new season kicked off. 
The big money is there, the new superstar players have arrived – just one small problem, no fans. Twitter 2 Opening game of Chinese Super League season between Guizhou Zhicheng and Liaoning Whowin with no fans 
Guizhou Zhicheng’s 52,888-seater stadium was virtually empty due to a stadium ban slapped on the club due to fans invading the pitch after sealing promotion to the top flight. Despite the hype and fanfare surrounding the lucrative league, a stadium ban was enforced for the hosts. Reuters Carlos Tevez is pocketing £615,000-a-week, out in China but will hope for decent crowds this season most read in football TORRES trauma Shocking moment Fernando Torres was saved from scoring and miraculous late winners drying up... what is going wrong for Zinedine Zidane at the Bernabeu? 
The game at the Guiyang Olympic Sports centre against Liaoning Whowin finished in a 1-1 draw. 
The CSL has sent shockwaves around in the footballing world, flexing it’s financial muscles to attract stars from Europe and South America, with eye-watering salaries to move to the far east. SunSport's Justin Allen goes to check out the Chinese Super League Chines top flights sides shelled out £320million on new players including Carlos Tevez, Oscar and Odioan Odion Ighalo. With the footballing eyes of the world watching, it's an embarrassing start to the new campaign with millions world wide watching a game played out in front of no fans.
